title: Electoral Systems
description: Discover how different countries choose their leaders through various voting and electoral systems

questions.question: In the U.S. Electoral College, how many electoral votes are needed to win the presidency?
What is 'proportional representation'?
options: Seats are allocated in proportion to votes received by each party
The candidate with the most money wins

questions.question: In a 'first-past-the-post' system, which candidate wins?
options: The one who reaches 50% of votes
The one approved by a committee
The one with the most votes, regardless of majority
The one who wins a runoff election

questions.question: Which country is famous for its compulsory voting system?
A 'referendum' is a vote in which the entire electorate is asked to decide on what?
options: Tax rates for the next year

questions.question: What is 'gerrymandering'?
options: Manipulating electoral district boundaries for political advantage

questions.question: In a 'ranked-choice voting' system, voters do what?
options: Vote only for their preferred party
Vote on separate days for each candidate
Vote for multiple candidates by ranking them in order of preference

questions.question: The French presidential election uses which voting system?
What is a 'caucus' in the context of U.S. elections?
options: A type of ballot counting method
A local gathering where party members discuss and vote for candidates

questions.question: New Zealand was the first self-governing country to grant women the right to vote in national elections, in which year?
The 'butterfly ballot' became infamous in U.S. politics due to confusion in which state during the 2000 election?
What is a 'primary election' in the United States?
options: An election for local offices only
A preliminary election to select a party's candidate

questions.question: Which European country uses a system called 'Mixed Member Proportional' representation?
In India, the Election Commission is responsible for conducting elections. India's general elections are the world's largest democratic exercise with how many eligible voters (approximately)?
What does the term 'suffrage' mean?
options: The right to run for office
The right to a fair trial
